qas.question: What types of retail offerings are found in Cork?

answers.text: state of the art shopping centres and family owned local shops

qas.question: What happened after the economy dropped off around 2008?

answers.text: many retail spaces available for let

qas.question: What major department stores gottheir starts in Cork?

answers.text: Dunnes Stores and the former Roches Stores

qas.question: When will work on the Grand Parade begin?
How large is the retail space in the Grand Parade proposed to be?
What is mostly a mix of family owned shops?
What mostly caters to expensive boutiques?

plausible_answers.text: Blackpool, Ballincollig, Douglas, Ballyvolane, Wilton and Mahon Point

qas.question: What nearby suburbs need to come to cork for shopping centers?
What area was effected by the economic growth of 2008?
What large mall is located in Ballyvolane?

plausible_answers.text: the site of the former Capitol Cineplex

qas.question: What site was Ballincollig built on?
How much retail space was Mahon Point approved for?
In what year will work begin on Mahon Point?

plausible_answers.text: the most expensive street in the country per sq. metre

qas.question: What is Opera Lane considered after Dublin Grafton Street?

context: <b5_0>The retail trade<b5_0/> in Cork city includes a mix of both modern, <a0_0>state of the art shopping centres and family owned local shops<a0_0/>. <b6_0>Department stores<b6_0/> cater for all budgets, with expensive boutiques for one end of the market and high street stores also available. Shopping centres can be found in many of Cork's suburbs, including <b7_0>Blackpool, Ballincollig, Douglas, Ballyvolane, Wilton and Mahon Point<b7_0/>. Others are available in the city centre. These include the recently[when?] completed development of two large malls <b9_0>The Cornmarket Centre<b9_0/> on Cornmarket Street, and new the retail street called "Opera Lane" off St. Patrick's Street/Academy Street. The Grand Parade scheme, on <b10_0>the site of the former Capitol Cineplex<b10_0/>, was planning-approved for <a4_0><b11_0>60,000 square feet (5,600 m2)<b11_0/><a4_0/> of retail space, with work commencing in <a3_0><b12_0>2016<b12_0/><a3_0/>. Cork's main shopping street is <b8_0>St. Patrick's Street<b8_0/> and is <b13_0>the most expensive street in the country per sq. metre<b13_0/> after Dublin's Grafton Street. As of 2015[update] this area has been impacted by the post-2008 downturn, with <a1_0>many retail spaces available for let<a1_0/>.[citation needed] Other shopping areas in the city centre include Oliver Plunkett St. and Grand Parade. Cork is also home to some of the country's leading department stores with the foundations of shops such as <a2_0>Dunnes Stores and the former Roches Stores<a2_0/> being laid in the city. Outside the city centre is Mahon Point Shopping Centre.
